i enjoyed this pretty much and i am very excited for the next season coming soon!

I didn't expect to enjoy this show as much as I did, but I guess I'm just a huge sucker for fairytale romance.
One evening I was bored, so I sat down to watch a couple episodes. Well, I enjoyed it so much that I went back and watched the rest of the series the next day! And I was not disappointed.
I don't even think I have anything negative to say about it. It was so sweet that it gave me cavities and I simply loved every moment. The story wasn't anything particularly unique, but there was something refreshing about watching such a sugary sweet fairytaleamid all the dark anime I've been watching lately. 


The animation was absolutely beautiful; as a matter of fact, I was just thinking the other day that I think the outfits the characters wear are amazing. Everyone just looks so sleek and colorful that I could stare at them all day. 


The music isn't anything special or extraordinarily memorable in my opinion, but I do think that the opening has a certain charm to it. I think it's really more the opening video than the song that gets to me, though.


Being only twelve episodes, they haven't gone into huge depth in the anime with many of the characters, but I don't really have any criticism for any of them. I love both Shirayuki and Zen the best. Shirayuki is a surprisingly likable female protagonist in that, unlike many fairytale-type heroines, she is strong and resourceful. Although she does need to be saved quite a few times in the series, she doesn't just sit around and wait like a damsel in distress, either. She's a smart girl and thinks things through, and I find myself cheering for her quite often. Zen is also a likeable character; he's heroic and dashing, as fairytale princes should be, but he is also kind and respectful to Shirayuki and does whatever he can to help her acheive her goals. Watching their adorable relationship develop is just so much fun :)


Anyway, Akagami no Shirayuki-hime is definitely one of my new favorites. I would probably recommend it to you if you like a sweet story, or otherwise enjoy fairytales or a good Disney movie. I think I might have to pick up the manga, sometime.

Short and sweet review. Do you know what to expect from romance anime and are tired of people pointing out the "genre stereotypes" and then judging the anime only around that? Just want to know the important stuff and if you should watch it? I've got you covered.
Note: This is a review of the entire 24 episode series.
I put off watching this one because of the "Snow White" title. I assumed it had something to do with the classic story. But I was wrong. It literally has almost nothing to do with it.
A girl with uncommon red hair is forced to flee her home countryafter being pursued by an arrogant prince. She winds up meeting the prince of a neighboring country while fleeing her pursuers and goes with him and his entourage back to the neighboring country. The story focuses on her as she strives to make a name for herself as a court herbalist and overcome people's skepticism about her as she grows closer to the prince in the country she escaped to.


I absolutely loved this show, until the end. The pacing, the characters, the art, the music. It was all great. I enjoyed every episode and flew through it because of how good it was. I hate romances that don't progress, and this one moved at a nice pace. I have no complaints about the show as a whole. It had a nice balance of action, drama, romance, and plot twists, which made it satisfying to watch.


The problem is the ending. This is another show that ended before it was complete. They try to give us the standard "Oh no we needed like another 24-48 episodes to properly deliver the ending of the story so here is an ambiguous shot of the characters together to give the impression their story continues and they stay together" ending. And I hate when romance anime do that.


Most genres can get away with series cliffhangers where there is no real resolution. But romances that do this ruin it. I was so invested in this story, and then it just ends. No resolution, no finding out what happens to them, just over.


And yes, I realize there is a manga I could read if I wanted a complete story arc. But I'm tired of that being the easy out for these anime that refuse to give us a resolution to the story we get invested in. I shouldn't have to change the type of media I am consuming just to have a resolution to the story. It's crap, and studios that do this just piss me off.


It's hard to recommend this show given that the ending is just non-existent, but everything else was so good that I think it is still worth it.


HIGHLIGHTS: Everything except the ending, great characters, pacing, and story (tried and true plot, but it's still entertaining)


DISAPPOINTMENTS: Oh my god, why make a romance anime without an ending? WHHYYYYYY?!?!?!

If dwarves were ever involved in this production, Disney would probably make sure it never saw the light of day. Thankfully, no dwarves are involved in this series.
The only resemblance to the classic Grimm fairy tale is a prop in the first arc of the production, and the word "apple" in the description of Shirayuki's hair. That's about it. Instead of a princess in exile living with a bunch of dwarves, Shirayuki is a humble herbalist living in the city. When the local spoiled prince decides he wants her as his plaything, she cuts off most of her hair, leaves it for the prince ("...since you appear to like my hair more than I do..."), and makes Billy Big-steps in the general direction away from the prince.


When I saw that scene, I applauded and said, "Well, he's going to need a bathtub full of lotion for that burn." This is the sort of spirit and quick thinking that is so often missing from heroine characters, and she demonstrates that quick mind at critical moments during the show. Sure, it's a "they all live happily ever after" kind of fairy tale (and I totally understand that this kind of predictability can be dull), but the way she gets out of bad situations is usually with her brain, and a little help from Prince Charming, I mean, Zen. The only exception is if she's imprisoned (this will come back to bite her character). I'm fine with the scenarios in this show, where every bad situation ends in a happy ending, because it does a decent job of making me wonder, "All right, Shirayuki, how are you going to get out of this one?"


Speaking of Zen, it's kinda fun to see a Prince Charming character who isn't dressed in white armor and riding a white horse, but instead, a guy who would much rather take a nap in the woods than do boring government work. He's a bit like Shouta Kazehaya from KimiTodo-- he's charming, and he seems flawless, but his biggest weakness is the heroine.


If there's a weakness I could point out, it's probably the villains and supporting characters. Because Shirayuki and Zen are the central foci of the show, everyone else isn't nearly as well fleshed-out (even with the "flashback" episodes). The villains are basically Bad Guy tropes of various forms-- we have a spoiled brat, a couple of manipulative gaslighters, and a cheating aristocrat. This adds to predictability, which could downgrade the experience for some.


Visually, the show is easy on the eyes. Nothing spectacular, but nothing conspicuously awful either. The soundtrack is a good orchestral one, the melodies for some reason bring to mind the audio from classic Disney films. I'm struggling to remember details and style, which probably means I should re-watch.


All told, a solid production for a straight-ahead, slow romantic drama. I particularly like how Shirayuki was written with a brain and not just another pretty face.

this review doesn't contain any spoilers and will be for both the first and second season of this anime.
story; 8/10
The story follows a young girl, Shirayuki, who possesses unusual beautiful red hair.
While in some moments, you might feel like they have exaggerated the appeal of this hair color and most of the plot revolves around it, please note that this anime is made to be cheesy. And that's mainly why most liked it (including me) I mean it's shoujo after all.
Now, Shirayuki lives in the country called Tanbarun and works as a pharmacist, as she knows a lot about herbs and medicine.
The prince of herhome country, asks her to become his mistress, just because of her hair, so she cuts it and runs off to Clarines, a neighboring country.


There, she meets Zen, Mitsuhide and Kiki, who she befriends. And Zen turns out to be the second prince of Clarines.


There, she starts working on becoming a court herbalist of Clarines.


It is kind of cliché, I mean you can just guess they're gonna fall in love and such. Also, I am not a big fan of shoujo.


Yet, to be honest, this anime has a weird habit of finding a way to hook you up more in each episode. The main plot might not look that exciting to you and it is somewhat predictable, but it is clear, straightforward and pretty nice actually.



art; 9/10


The art is what i loved the most, to be completely honest. It is very pleasing and really beautiful.


It's just great I'm telling you.


The scenes are absolutely gorgeous and I don't know I just like it a lot.



sound; 7/10


The openings and endings were nice and really fitting to the anime, I definitely didn't dislike them, but I can easily say that I forgot all about them the minute I finished the anime.


I also quite liked the soundtrack. Just like the openings and endings, the soundtrack is extremely fitting in each moment and well chosen, I guess.


They are pretty light and don't distract you from the anime and are really enjoyable.



characters; 8/10


The character developments are not massive for the main characters. There is, of course, but the anime seems to focus more on the secondary characters' developments.


Why? Well I feel like the mains keep influencing the people around them, just like they charm the audience, in a way.


So yeah, you might not see a lot of character development in Zen and Shirayuki but instead in people like Raj, Obi, etc.


Anyway, what I loved about the characters is that they're quite realistic.


You might feel like Shirayuki is a bit... too loved in some moments, but in the end, she doesn't have any supernatural ability, she's not overly badass, nor too weak; she's simply realistic.


She's bold, strong-willed, hardworking, selfless and kindheartedj but it never seems out of place or too cliché-like. I've never been able to see her as a Mary Sue.


Meanwhile, Zen is really strong and very stubborn, he is also hardworking. He's really nice to other people and is absolutely adorable in my opinion.


But in the end, it's not just them, there are tons of amazing characters that have lots of potential. (my favorites are Obi and Raj, just saying)



enjoyment; 7/10


Even if I sometimes got bored, as I said before this anime has a habit of finding ways and plots to hook me up more in each episode.


The story is pretty slow-paced also but is somewhat always satisfying in the end?


I loved the anime and I'm looking forward to reading the manga as well.



overall; 8/10


Akagami no Shirayuki-hime is a really good anime, in my opinion, and I think people should really give it a shot, because it's worth it.


So if you're searching for a cheesy yet interesting plotline with cute couples and awesome characters; look no more! This anime will be perfect for you.

Akagami no Shirayukihime is, in many ways, your usual shoujo anime. It is cheesy, trope-y and at every level almost laughably predictable. The premise isn’t particularly unique, the characters aren’t especially unique, and after watching a few episodes, you will have a good idea of how the rest of the show will play out. Despite all of this, Akagami no Shirayukihime still manages to stand out amongst the yearly deluge of mediocre shoujo series.
It becomes quickly evident that plot is not a major focus of this series. While there is a premise, and the show has a few ‘story arcs’ in a sense, much ofthe show will feel very much like a slice-of-life anime. The premise, events, and the conflicts introduced themselves are not particularly original. Overall, the plot takes a backseat in favour of developing its characters’ relationships, and this is where I think this show shines.


The focus the characters and their dynamics means that they become believable. Instead of falling into the easy stereotypes of the characters’ roles (e.g. the devoted aide, the antagonistic older prince), and expecting those stereotypes to be accepted for what they are, major characters' motivations are established through a good balance of backstory and interaction, and in a very straightforward manner. This also means that it doesn’t feel like the show treats its audience like idiots. Everything is given a strong foundation, allowing the show to progress unhindered by contradictions that need to be hurriedly explained away.


This is especially enjoyable to experience as Zen and Shirayuki’s relationship progresses. From the beginning of the show, Shirayuki is established as an intelligent, independent character who wishes to live by her own merit. She is a ‘strong female character’, but in a believable way - her strengths manifest in multiple dimensions, but so do her weaknesses. Most importantly, these traits are not tossed to the side in favour of her pursuing a romance. Zen, as well, is refreshing as a male protagonist. Despite the evident power imbalance in the relationship, which is one of the most major sources of conflict in the show, he is at all times respectful of Shirayuki’s need to be independent, a trait that he retains as his romantic feelings for her grow. When their relationship culminates towards the end of the show, it remains apparent that Zen values Shirayuki's friendship, companionship and intelligence over his own feelings. It is satisfyingly evident that their relationship is built on mutual respect, trust, and love. 


Technically, this anime is well-executed. As an old fan of the manga, I was initially disappointed at the slight change in style, however, the show is vibrant, the animation smooth, and the art mostly consistent. While there is no particular flourish to the show, it still at time manages to be a visual treat. The sound is good, with the music serving its purpose in terms of establishing atmosphere and elevating emotional scenes, though not particularly memorable


Overall, this show is one I can easily recommend to anyone looking for a feel-good romance shoujo anime, and perhaps some people outside of that description.

Oh my goodness I can't explain how much I loved Akagami no Shirayuki-hime.
Well, I don't really like how the main character ran away from her town over such a small problem but ok, and why did she cut her hair? Seriously she should have kept it, she was still found anyways :(.
Also, I don't really like how the main character is loved by like everyone... I mean maybe one or two people but when almost everyone in the anime likes her it's kind of weird.
Anyways, I really liked the romance of the story and the storyline overall. I liked how the relationship progressed between thetwo main characters. It could be very romantic during some scenes. I liked how cute and romantic this story was.


It also had a few really sad scenes at some points...


I feel bad for one of the characters though who is not seen the same way by the main character, but begins to see her in that way. She doesn't really notice it although.


I will definitely be watching the second season, just waiting for the 12th episode to come out first so I don't have to wait in suspense if I catch up on it before it's released. ^-^

Now, let me tell you why Akagami no Shirayuki-hime stole my heart:
Story-8: Now, I may be biased because I love this anime, but the story really isn't bad. The female lead isn't useless and the male lead isn't perfect, and their romance is something else. I must applaud the script writer. This anime is the definition of my perfect romance. Shirayuki flees to another kingdom to escape marriage to a selfish prince. And on her way she meets Zen, second prince of Clarines. But the thing is, Zen doesn't try to swoon in and steal Shirayuki, and Shirayuki isn't crazy in love with Zen. Theirromance is something I've never seen. It's so realistic, yet such a child's fantasy. It's perfect.


Art-8: The art is beautiful. It's not stunning, but beautiful. The town is so whimsical, but still practical. The characters and their attire are proportionate and not too revealing or impractical (you know what I'm talking about). It's great.


Sound-6: The only thing that wasn't phenomenal was the sound. The voices of the characters were practical, nothing super annoying, and the nature sounds (tree rustling, birds, etc.) were accurate. But the music in general wasn't anything too great. I enjoyed the soundtrack in the intro and outdo, but otherwise it could have been better. 


Character-9: I am very emotionally attached to the characters. As the story progresses you learn to love every single character, even if they're the bad guys. Not to mention the main characters are super 'human.' Meaning, they portray their emotions just like us. There isn't any crazy super powers or drama queens. 


Enjoyment-9: I would say it's pretty obvious that I really enjoyed this anime. I am definitely planning to re-watch this anime and read the manga. 


Overall-10: Outstanding by all means. This anime is my ideal romance with everything a anime should have.

This Review Applies to Both Seasons of Akagami no Shirayuki-hime
It is rare that I stumble upon a genuinely light hearted but also entertaining romance story. Especially when the Romance story is set in medieval times, and it found itself to be one of the more enjoyable and interesting show even though, not much happened. (The video review is up on my channel, here is the written)
Story - 7/10
Once upon a time, there was girl with beautiful Red Hair, which is considered to be very rare and very special in this world. The girl, Shirayuki gets asked to become the prince’s concubine. Shirayuki of course uncomfortablewith the idea and knowing will pursue her, she runs off looking for a new life. Along the way she meets Prince Zen from the Kingdom of Clarines. After a shaky a start with the Zen, the two hit off off and begin to respect each other. But neither one of them wants to feel like a burden or give off the wrong impression to each other. Shirayuki begins to live in Clarines and she becomes a Herbal Medicine Doctor in the Kingdom in order for her to stand on equal footing as Zen. While Zen on the other hand, makes sure he does his job responsibly, to make sure Shirayuki doesn’t get the wrong impression of him. And you can probably tell where the Romance in this story is already.


I really like the stories of Shirayuki and Zen and their friends, most are really entertaining and interesting to watch. I kind of wish I knew where the story was going at the start and was hoping for a little more focus on the actual relationship between Shirayuki and Zen, because at times you wouldn’t really know where they are in their relationship. This show is basically broken into a lot of arcs that is all about the characters building chemistry with each other. But with a lack of overall plot goal and ending, you really don’t get into the story that much. But that doesn’t mean that the setting of the show and the whole world building and the general story isn’t interesting, because it is. Even though it has little focus, it is still interesting, and that is because of the character dynamics. 


Characters - 10/10


Speaking of characters, Shirayuki is the main protagonist and just some fun trivia, ‘Shira’ means ‘white’ and ‘yuki’ means ‘snow’ so you get the idea where the name Snow White comes from in this show. Shirayuki gets quite the development considering the show is involved around her. She learns about her new life and realises she needs to earn the respect in order to stand on equal footing with the prince. She doesn’t want be portrayed as a typical damsel spoilt princess, that doesn’t suit her. So she works hard to gain respect from everyone. Of course along the way she changes those around her especially when it came to Obi, her bodyguard and surprisingly Prince Raj, from Tabarun the country she ran away from. As the show progresses she starts developing feelings of Zen, and I would’ve love to see more in their lovers relationship.


Zen is other character in this relationship. Zen is a the Prince of Clarines. Zen on the other hand is considered to be a well-respected Prince, although he doesn’t show that much enthusiasm to his role, that doesn’t stop him from doing his job when needed. Due to him giving off the wrong impression on Shirayuki when they first met, he actually starts trying harder to gaining Shirayuki’s respect, so she doesn’t get the wrong impression on him, because he knew how she saw how up themselves royalty can be. Zen, like Shirayuki develops with others around him and starts learning more how he can become a good respected Prince, of course as well he himself starts developing feelings for Shirayuki. 


Obi, is Shirayuki’s bodyguard and Zen’s messenger. Although Obi starts off completely on wrong foot trying with both them, with him being ordered to threaten Shirayuki and losing Zen’s trust at first, he probably gets the most development in the series. He starts learn about his friends and grows as a person who is trying to fix his old habits and genuinely shows concern to all the other characters. This while being the best third wheel, anyone can ask for. 


What I think is the best aspect of the show is the characters in general, and even the supporting cast get enough time and development, so we genuinely show much more interest in them as well. Mitsuhide and Kiki, Zen’s bodyguards actually get backstories of how they all came to be, which is a really nice added to touch to make us care about these characters. And I wasn’t even expecting this, even, Prince Raj, who Shirayuki ran away from initially, gets amazing development during the second cour. All the supporting characters are interesting and get enough growth for you to genuinely take interest in them and they all play with each other so well. Their interactions are really well done.


Animation and Sound - 8/10 6/10


Being made by studio Bones, I usually would expect quite top notch animation. And it definitely shines in this anime. The scenery in this medieval fantasy world looks gorgeous and the colours are amazing to look at.  Each character has unique designs, so it’s easy to tell each of them apart. What I love about the animation, is that even though its mostly light hearted, so you don’t see too much action, but when they do, it’s generally pretty subtle and good, which fits with the show. Except for one noticeable scene where Obi was fighting. If there is one thing they done perfectly is, get Shirayuki’s hair done right, because if having Red hair is special in their world, you better bet that the red hair is beautiful, which it is. It’s really refreshing to look at.


As for the soundtrack you get a pretty standard tracklist of classical music. Really mellow most of the time with nothing really standing out too much. It does feel like classical orchestra, but in honesty it kind of sounds all very similar. Even for the more intense scenes, it just feels like they’re playing it faster. The Opening songs are really nice to listen to. I like the light hearted upbeat vibe or the first opening, whereas the second opening really sounds like something for an adventure anime. Oh yeah and the voice actress of Shirayuki sing the opening. The ending songs, aren’t really that special, it’s ok, but rather forgettable.


Enjoyment - 8/10


For me this was one of the surprising shows I’ve watched. I genuinely wasn’t very interested in watching something like this, but as it went on, it caught my attention and I started loving it. Because the characters are all amazing and their interactions with each other a really well written. Add that with the fact every character is trying to achieve something of their own, makes it worth watching, because it’s interesting to see where they go from where they started. The show is a bit slow to start off with, as you don’t really see much focus during the first cour, however during the second cour, there is a lot more happening to leading to more exciting storylines to follow.


Verdict - 8/10


As near towards the end of the review, I give the story a 7. Even though the overall story seems a bit lacking with not much focus, the individual arcs are interesting enough to watch, while the world building is done very well, to keep us engaged.


For the animation and sound, I give it a 8 and 6. The art style looks wonderful, it’s beautiful to look at. It really showcases the fantasy world the characters are in. Some of the animation is inconsistent, and the action scenes aren’t really exciting. But they completely nailed Shirayuki’s hair colour. The soundtrack uses good classical music, although it can get repetitive. The openings are great though, they really bring out a nice adventure and light hearted vibe.


For the characters I give it a 10. I loved how every character was fleshed out and not many characters were left behind. Each character got surprisingly good development. And the chemistry among the characters are a joy to watch. Shirayuki and Zen’s relationship was done very well, and I loved how they played on each other perfectly.


As for my own personal enjoyment, I give it a 8. There wasn’t really too much exciting things happening in the anime, it was more of an interesting watch, due to seeing how the relationships grew among the characters. However the world building and character interactions are what made this anime very enjoyable to watch. It has a cute romance plot I can get behind as well.


So for the overall score after rounding it all up, I give Akagami no Shirayukihime a 8/10. It’s a really character focused anime, they really bring out the potential in all their characters. I recommend this anime to Shoujo fans, especially if you love Romance anime and maybe those who would love to watch medieval slice of life.

A simple story with somewhat compelling characters. It's definitely a shoujo anime/manga with many sweet and innocent scenes. Some may be cheesy, some may be cliches, and some may contain both. But otherwise, what romantic film isn't these days. The drama is very light, and I feel like I was watching an Atelier series, a JRPG game with usually, it is the female as heroine. Overall, it is a must for people who are into romance, fantasy, and somewhat unrealistic characters. If you want to read more of my review, look no more, because I'll explain more in depth on the bottom. For those whojust want to know right away, simply don't watch it if you aren't into romantic cheesy and cliches moments. But otherwise, it wouldn't hurt to watch one or two episode for people who aren't into romance.


Story: It rather plain and simple, which isn't a bad thing. Sometimes making a story-line that is too complex and confusing can simply ruin the whole show. For a romantic show, a simple story-line is the way to go. Without spoiling anything much, it simply about a girl who wants to choose her own path rather than being forced by another. Upon meeting a person, she became interest in this person and wish to know more as she pursue her answer. Eventually, she does find her answer early on, the person she met also start having feelings for her. And as each episode goes, the story also develops. The bad part is there is no absolute twist. Not much of a plot and not much of a story.


Art: I'm not much of an art person so I don't have much to say other than it is a delight to look at. I don't feel impulse even with characters who "bad" people or "antagonist" themselves. This can be a good thing and a bad thing. Since I don't feel anything much from a bad person, it also say that they're not really unique and memorable like how I see Griffith in Berserk as a cool, yet horrifying character. But the art does stand out in its' own merit and that is the fantasy setting. Because of that, everything and everywhere I look feels a lot more like the Atelier series, in which I very much like playing. It feel calming, spiritually, and just want you to smile awkwardly. But otherwise, if there is a bad, it would be that it can be bland at times.


Sound: Perhaps I may be bias in this one because I love violin sounds. Pretty much any classical playing is my favorite sounds. I would give this a 10/10, but I felt most of the music was, more or less, the same thing. However, that's the only the only down part. Everything else is really nice to listen to. It felt really appropriate to the setting of Fantasy and Romance genre. Opening and ending are great as it is, but probably could be better. 


Character: As well as the story was simplistic, characters felt a little too simple and unrealistic as well. I like that the main characters are nice and sweet, but it feel like one-dimensional. I understand, there is still the 2nd season, in which, I haven't watch, but I felt the character development is fine, but should have more personality to them. I feel like the characters are "too good to be true." Yes, it is a fantasy-romantic genre, and yes, it is an anime. But even anime can try to be realistic in someway. And by realistic, I mean believable. When watching the complete first season, Shirayuki feels a like a passionate (mentally) strong woman, but also with kindness and her concern for other over herself. This wouldn't be a bad thing if there wasn't so many anime character like her already. I would like to see her angry side. Same goes to Prince Zen. but at least, on Zen's side, there a little more to it because he has more background story so far. Obi as far as it goes, a mysterious character. Hopefully we learn more about him. Mitsuhide can be a interesting character, but for now, I feel like he is just there for convenient moments. For Kiki, I don't know what to say, is she just a simple caretaker for Prince Zen, or what, I don't know what other role she play, but she is even more mysterious than Obi. As far as it goes, there should never be two people with mysterious background because it lacks depth for each characters. I hope it does goes more into it for Second season.


Enjoyment: Like I have said, it was very much like watching an Atelier series, but instead of playing the game, I am watching it. It definitely  a good watch in my book, but I can see why some people may get bored with it at some point as it doesn't really add anything much to the story other than watching characters develop and making the story themselves.


Overall: It's a good show to watch. There are obvious flaws, but not enough to say that it is a terrible anime. But I highly recommend that you only watch it if you into light-humor with nice Fantasy setting and strongly into romance. Of course, it's also a good show to relax from all seriousness. If none of this speak to you, look somewhere else.

Here we go, another beautiful looking anime, great feeling of medieval fantasy, and... a cliche filled story... dammit!
Shirayuki is the most strong-willed, independent and brave damsel in distress I have ever seen. It's like the author thought, hey she is strong, this is not a cliche, and then puts her in all the cliche situations possible.
Zen is the gallant prince, brave, just and handsome, textbook cliche.
The story is brain dead, just from seeing the first episodes. She has red hair and so everyone seems to want to rape, sell or hurt her for some reason, unless they are not which means they absolutely loveher. They don't even explain what is wrong with her having red hair, people just say it is rare. That is all nice, hey, red hair is not that common anyway, but just as this is said a character who is a friend of the prince walks in with green hair and no one bats an eye.  In one part she is in distress and almost gets out unaided and I was like, hey maybe I misjudged... nope. The bad guy tells her that even if she escapes they are in a mountain only he knows well. Surprise, just as he is about to hit her the prince appears. Check this, it has been a whole day of her kidnapping, he takes a ship to get where she was exploring, for some reason climbs the exact mountain only the bad guy knew, like he had a GPS tracker on her and saves her just in the nick of time, and this is never explained (which is obvious, after all there is basically no way to justify this scene) Hey, I love a good romance story, but this one is not even trying, so I am not gonna try either.\n

Snow White is the oldest Disney’s princess fairy tale, it portrays a woman characteristics that is weak, good-for-nothing-except-house-chores. It is indeed a fairy tale, where you were saved by your stranger prince from your evil step-mother, but it does not tackle woman’s ability of self-independence. Here in Akagami no Shirayuki-hime, Shirayuki is an herbalist, an independent, intelligent and skilled woman. She is wise, dependable and mature way beyond her age, as she supports her living by herself. The story would be fantastic if only it was been discussed properly. It is absurd thatpeople will go crazy too much just because one person was born with such rarity. It’s okay that people will go on talk about it everywhere; I understand that, but to kidnap one? To offer such social status just for that is a complete nonsense. The story itself is too fast-paced, wherein too much events are occurring at the same time, which results in poor deliberation of proper storyline from the beginning to the end. Most of anime only have 12 episodes, which most anime released nowadays are poor with the development no matter how much the idea; the structure of the story is magnificent as our favorite fairy tale unicorn. Akagami no Shirayuki-hime has joined the bandwagon of poor anime; no matter how much potential I can see if only it was portrayed professionally. The relationship and self-development is the main reason for its destruction, it was too sudden, and then it was not. The character’s development is deadly confusing; it has no path where it’s headed to. Akagami no Shirayuki-hime can have both turn of events: with or without having climax. Climax is very important in every art because it brings heaviness- more depth to the portrait it wants to deliver. Which more reason why Akagami no Shirayuki-hime is such a “bummer” for being wasted when it has such a lot of potential, there’s no many anime that can give out both options of with or without climax. If there are in these 12 episodes, you can certainly not see it, as if it was being transparent to half percent which is not good, because an excellent story should be absolute. This anime was not executed as it meant to.


If there’s one thing I’m sure of this anime is that Shirayuki is so loved by everyone. People love and go for her is because of her unusual hair color, which all the reason why she ran from Tanbarun, her specialness from her red hair is what prince Raj of her country wants her to be his concubine, which is why she cut her hair and flee away from home, only to run to the second prince of her country’s neighboring kingdom. What a coincidence! She threw her life in Tanbarun, her beloved home, where all people adore her, just because prince Raj wants to pamper her like a wife without actually marrying her. She could have a talk to the prince or when the tables have been turned, she could have escape from prison and be her own superhero. Zen saved her, which has been instantly become her ‘special friend’. What mostly annoys me is that feelings between Zen and Shirayuki developed too suddenly, too fast, too rushed. I could already feel from the second episode that Zen and Shirayuk have feelings for each other, too obvious. They should have self-development first, building relationships with each other, to bring a castle of proper shoujo romance. Instead of watching a dove wrapped themselves like a heart-shaped in the pond, I’m watching instead a 3-year old boy and girl telling themselves they are in love. I can find the proper development to Obi when it comes to love, slowly but absolute. Curious to wondering, Obi is slowly approaching to find what affection is, carefully but surely, Obi has captured me to raise my hand in volunteer to be his “shoujo” instead.


I’m not a picky eater, and that goes same to graphics and sounds. I actually don’t care if the transition of the graphics is too much or too little because I believe that animation is not important, the story, the character development and the enjoyment should be the standard of judging whether or not the anime is worth the hype. Although there are few things to comment, like the at the first episode when prince Raj is panicking when Zen revealed himself as the second prince of Clarines, instead of watching a defeat, I’m watching instead a gag because of prince Raj’s face. It would be also great if they would add more music, give more intensity while events are happening.


The enjoyment of this anime is… meh. Not boring but not exciting. I did quite enjoy this anime because for the reason I keep on wondering and searching when this anime will have a character development, which later revealed that there’s no such thing. Turns out my hype over it was good for nothing. I honestly enjoyed the hug and kissing scene other than that, no more else. Glad those scenes are unexpected and surprising.


There’s nothing about Shirayuki’s life that is a problem. She was happy before and she is happy now. She passed easily the test for Clarines’ court apprentice herbalist, there’s nothing hard for Shirayuki’s life, she stood up for herself before, and same goes for the present time too. This is just a story of protagonist’s life being simply perfect at every corner, which there’s no reason why you don’t need to tell it anymore to anybody. There’s no meaning if there is nothing to stake, like I’ve mentioned earlier, this would be a potential anime if there is really a struggle and growth of characters, but it doesn’t exist here. There’s so much story to tell about Shirayuki and the people around her like Zen, Raj, Kiki, Mitsuhide and Obi, but it didn’t happen. Thus, this anime became a supposed-to-be-a-great-potential to a shame.

So because I just finished this anime and everything is still fresh on my mind I thought I'd write a review for it since it's been a pretty popular this year for romance anime. 
Starting off I just want to put out there that while the title is Snow White with the Red Hair the story has very little relation to the original tale of Disney's Snow White. Like maybe the first 2 episodes and a little later in the series play to similar story aspects. So don't expect 7 little men and a beautiful heroine being poisoned by a witch only to be broughtback with a kiss.


This anime pretty much is a story of it's own and it's like they just threw references to the original in across the series and went with it. Frankly, I think I'd think this would have been more creative if the name of the series was different and it had the references of snow white kept in it. It would have gotten a few more points from me if that was the case.  


Anyway, with that aside this series is very popular for a fairy tale story concepts of princes and princesses falling in love, and with having that sort of concept I must say it's not that bad of a story. I don't think some people reviewing or talking about this anime are really considering that this is mainly targeted and popular amongst adolescent girls. I mean it's somewhat based on the original snow white so by default it's going to be very cheesy and cliché. 


Some flaws I did find aside from the cheesy and cliché concepts were the triangles of love and this odd heroine appeal that continue up into season 2. This girl is a red haired beauty and I guess it is weird to have apple red hair but if she's going to have that sort of hair and it be centered around why she's so unique then why doesn't everyone have normal hair color where it stands out even more? Most of the characters do have pretty normal hair colors, but one of the guards literally has greenish blue hair. Like why is she special and not him? 


Aside from that the love triangles, for which I'm holding back details to prevent spoilers, are sort of nonsense. Like it's okay if it's between two princes or something but most every man she knows sort of likes her on the side. It's to the point of reverse harem even though it's obvious she only has feelings for one guy. Which even if you like that sort of thing it's sort of like they cut the romance down a lot. 


There is 2 seasons of this anime and there really isn't a ton of development between the romance between Snow White and Zen, who from the first episodes is obviously the main love interest. It's kind of consistent on they like each other but sort of just like best friends who occasionally kiss, but if you like that gentle sort of slow progressing romance then that probably won't bother you as much. I just expected more I guess especially since from reading up there won't be another season. 


On some things I liked, I enjoyed the humor in this series for it keeps things more light and not so dry. Also most of the characters I really enkoyed their independent personalities and the sort of direction they give to advancing the story. You can really see the connections to the characters and how they grow in response to others. 


The main character, while the epitome of someone with first world problems, is also not that dull and boring because she's very determined and strong. She's not a typical ditz and she doesn't let a relationship with royalty affect determination she has. I find it interesting she's a healer in this story too because I think it shows she's very intelligent and all though this sort of perfection and courage might not be appealing I actually enjoyed it. 


The story was okay I think personally this first season was a little bit better in my taste, but that's a preference thing on what kind of story elements you enjoy. As far as the second season I think more could have been explained or progressed but still that's my opinion. The art was very beautiful and the color of the imagery really stood out because the scenery is so bright and detailed. As well as the music which stayed true the type of time period elements as well as being very graceful and pretty. 


Overall I thought this was a good anime, thought a lot of things could have been better executed, but for the most part it wasn't bad. This is something I'd probably more enjoy like 3 years ago or maybe someone younger who likes fairy tale romance might like. If you're older this is obviously probably going to bore you or you might think this anime is lacking so I'd say if you want to pass it off go for it but be aware of target audience. It's not my favorite of the year but I think it holds it's own.

This is one of my favorite mangas and the anime adaptation has done a wonderful job with it. It's hard to know if my rating or review is overly biased but, if it is, that's only because I've been won over by these characters from quite a long while ago.
I appreciate the fact that the story is willing to take older, tried and true elements and work with them in a way that shows a uniqueness and creativity. I think people sometimes miss the actual tie-ins with the old fairy tale Snow White but I feel like recognizing that helps to appreciate the meld ofEastern and Western sensibilities. We see the fairy tale elements of a young girl facing powerful nobility and having to take refuge in the woods. We have the prince charming. We even have the poisoned apples. Some of the common shoujo tropes make appearances throughout and anyone with familiarity will spot them weaving through. Not making any changes would have resulted in something predictable and uninteresting and over-compensating and just fully reinventing the wheel here would have been too much. This anime addresses these plot points and story arcs with grace and a clear direction. The one fault that could possibly hold water is how long it really takes to really get to something meaty. 


The art was done incredibly well. Attention to detail was spot-on, beautiful backgrounds with intricate work colored every scene, animations were smooth and the lighting was just absolutely stunning. 


The characters are almost too good. I do actually mean that as a slight criticism. A little too perfect, even in their shortcomings, and a little too unrealistic. But, despite that, they're easy to fall in love with. Our main character takes a while to flesh out as she comes across a little too two dimensional in the beginning and it's not until we see her face difficulties within herself that she really begins to feel real. The male lead and side characters are easy to love almost from the get-go and the interactions between the group show a very healthy and wonderful dynamic that helps to keep the story propped up well.


Overall, this anime may not be for everyone. If you want a lot of action or high levels of drama you won't find it here. This isn't an anime to get your adrenaline pumping or keep you in suspense. This is, however, a very sweet story with solid characters. It's good for a bolstering of the heart.

Akagami no Shirayuki-hime was recommended to me by my friend, and I had heard about it a lot so I decided to check it out. However, when I checked it out, the first episode didn't really have a hook or anything special to it. The rest of the episodes were decent but not very enjoyable. I think this anime could've had a ton of potential, but the story was just way too unstable. The plot just kept switching every two episodes or so, and it was sometimes hard to follow what was going on. However, I do think that the characters were constructed beautifully, andwere pleasing to watch interact. Overall, I think this anime wasn't really anything special, but I do plan on watching the second season.

Alright, so, I put my rating as a 5 and I'll tell you why:
Story: 4/10
The story/plot is going absolutely no where in this anime. So first red hair (I forgot her name,so I'll just call her red hair) was in a village with a happy life. Then, the horny-ass prince suddenly liked her because of her hair color. Like WTF?! Who the hell would like someone just because of a hair color? Red hair's hair has NO relation to the story whatsoever. The only reason they put her with red hair is because they needed an excuse for red hair to run away and tofind her "prince" in the forest. Also, when red hair meets Prince Zen and becomes the castle's herbalist, she just went back to what her old-self was back in the village, but only in a castle and with shorter hair. The romance wasn't that good either. Actually, the only romance I saw was only in ONE episode in the whole series. At the start I was hooked in, but after the I don't know 6th, 7th, or 8th episode it was just getting plain boring.


Art: 7/10


To be honest, I think the only decent thing about this anime is the art. The art was okay, not so wowing or anything. Sometimes, the background was dull or boring.


Sound: 7/10


So, I really don't judge an anime based on the intro or outro, mostly because I skip them. But I do judge based on voice overs. The voice over was decent nothing that special. I've heard better though.


Character: 4/10


The characters... where to start. Oh yeah, the characters don't get developed whatsoever. Period. End of story. Actually, let me add on something... perfect lives. Red hair's life is so perfect that it's boring as hell.



Enjoyment: 5/10


Overall:5/10



So, if you want an anime where characters get developed, has a good romance, and has a plot twist, or actually a GOOD plot, then I wouldn't recommend this to you.

I personally loved the manga, and the anime is delivering well! The characters in these series are not anime cliches, Shirayuki is strong-- but not overly, along with able to face adversities without being a cry baby about them. She's not afraid to take risks. Zen the main male protagonist isn't a cliche either, he doesn't automatically trust Shirayuki, she earns it for herself. They're is a certain respect between the characters that makes it seem real, as they actually go through character development. (plus they are like the cutest relationship ever) the bond they share is so amazing.
The art is quite well done, thoughthe characters do look quite a bit childish. The story itself moves fast in the first episode, and has similarities to snow white, but after the first episode things move away from that base. The story overall looks enjoyable, and if sticking close to the manga could end up a masterpiece.
