Note: This review covers my overall thoughts of both seasons of Snow White with the Red Hair.
As its title would suggest, Snow White with the Red Hair is a fairy tale romance, with most of the typical trappings of the genre. The plot is simple, straight forward, and heavily focused on the romance, the writing can be very corny and schmultz-y, and the ending is the same as every fairy tale you have heard. However, if you are looking for a romance anime, and don't mind dialogue that can occasionally be too corny for its own good, then Snow White with the Red Hair mightbe the perfect show for you. This show does have a romance that avoids other love story cliches that, like me, you might find annoying. There are no love triangles, pointless drama, or unnecessary drama that is just meant to jerk the audience around. More importantly, our lead characters are not just 2 dimensional, tropes (tsundere, kuudere, dandere, etc.) that are often found in romance anime. The romance in this show is, for the most part, very believable and our two lead characters  are actually 3 dimensional characters that are capable of displaying more than 2 emotions.\n
Perhaps it is my lack of a lot of experience with romance animes that causes me to rate this series so highly, but I think this show has a great romance. The show avoids a lot of annoying cliches found in romance anime, and love stories in general, the romance is very believable, and our lead characters are 3 dimensional and actually have pretty good chemistry.

In this season we meet a main character that runs away from all she knows to start a new life in a strange country because she didn't want to be a prince's object of lust. She's smart, brave, dedicated and filled with quiet determination. You go girl!
Of course she captures the heart of another prince and then we get romance. Of course the author knows fuck all about court politics, intrigue or What A Royal Does (it involves signing papers maybe??? ¬¬), but we can let that go because it's a chill anime. Slice of life in a secondary world. There is a skilled maincharacter, a prince with a female bodyguard, very little damseling and a kick ass scene about how a knowledgeable human can escape imprisonment by being brave, resourceful and, well, running.\n
This is a series I can get behind. Let's hope the second season keeps up!\n

I don't understand the hype around this show. It's just the personification of a cliche Mary Sue character who runs away from her life just to conveniently run into the perfect man of her dreams, Gary Sue.
Where are her flaws like honestly
She had a nice life and was well-loved by everyone, and even after running off she still has a nice life and is well-loved. So where is the plot? I guess she didn't want to become a concubine or whatever but come on, there was barely anything to even enjoy other than everyone talking about how lovely the main girl is and how sheand Zen should get married or something\n\n
The red hair part is just out of place and fits awkwardly into the story\n\n
The story was mind boggling I still have yet to figure out what the hell was happening in this show

This anime is so bland and so shallow. I hate it when they serve romance in a silver platter without even any particular backstory or challenge. In this anime, protagonists: Shirayuki and Zen just suddenly fall in love with each other for no particular deep reason. Just, for some reason they're attracted to each other and for some reason they're suddenly inseparable and the best of friends. This anime has no particular solid plot whatsoever. I have picked up this anime just because it was recommended as something similar to Akatsuki no Yona. Believe me, it's a real disappointment. True enough, Shirayuki has balls ofsteel, can fend for herself and all that and has red hair just like Yona, but it's just that. No other similarity. Anime has other characters you would barely care about as they don't have any particular back story and would leave you without any attachment to any of them thus wouldn't care about their existence in the first place. I don't get why this anime even got a second season at all.

As someone who has delved into writing romantic stories and relationships, I can say with experience that it is far more difficult than most other forms of stories. Creating a believable, likable, and fun relationship that progresses and evolves both characters is something commendable and very difficult. And that is easily the greatest success of Snow White with the Red Hair.
Even a big fan of the show like me can admit that the story is nothing all that special, it mostly just follows the characters on their endeavors and explores their relationships. But, it does it's job without feeling complicated or holding the show back.
Thebest part of the show is the characters. First is Shirayuki, who is a very likable main protagonist. I like how she is mature and mostly independent, feeling the need to solve things without help. She's kind hearted, sweet, and well rounded. Zen is also a great character. He's a very well spoken individual who can be pretty awesome when he wants to be. He is a bit rebellious, but also cares about his people and does his best to be a good prince. His two aides of Kiki and Mitsuhide are also fun characters, who have a fun dynamic with both each other, as well as Zen and Shirayuki. I especially like the dynamic between Mitsuhide and Zen, they feel like genuine friends. The last main character is Obi, who I find hard to explain, but nonetheless, he is a ton of fun.


The music and the animation are both quite good, while not exactly being too noteworthy to explain in detail. They do their jobs just fine.


The romance between Zen and Shirayuki feels alive and well written, as the two have a lot of great banter and genuinely sweet moments that help build them as characters. They don't just say they're in love and kiss a lot, they actually act like it, by doing whatever they can for the other. They talk about their feelings, their worries, what they like about the other, while making it all still interesting. And this, like I said before, is the strongest element of the anime, and what helps make both of these characters stick out to me.


While the anime might not be anything unique, it still shines as a great example of romance and characters done totally right. It brought me a lot of joy and good feelings while still having great substance. It also gave me a lot of Spice and Wolf vibes, which, if you enjoy this anime, you should see that one, and vice versa. It has risen to be one of my top 5 favorites for good reasons.

One of the things I liked so much about this show (both seasons) is the character development and interaction. There's not so many twisty turns and plots, but the characters drive the story forward in such a way that elaborate plots aren't necessary. The main female protagonist, Shirayuki, is a confident, wholesome, intelligent woman. I love that she's an herbalist. The way she uses her herbal skills to handle situations was clever; She proves you don't always need fancy martial arts skills to get out of trouble. Another thing: In some stories you will get interactions that seem unrealistic, exaggerated even. Not so much inAkagami no Shirayuki hime. Characters on the show don't always explicitly say how they feel, but show us in subtle ways. To me that's how it is in real life. Of course I appreciated the romantic aspects of this show, this was easily one of the best romance anime I've watched ;) But actually, Akagami no Shirayuki hime showed the camaraderie in platonic relationships as well, in a way which I appreciated. Man I wish there was a 3rd season.

Likes:
The art for this anime was just fantastic. It was one of my favorite things about this anime. The character art was gorgeous. I especially liked the art for Mitsuhide, Ryu, and Obi. Obi looked like a cat. OBI, MITSUHIDE, RYU But the other characters kinda blended together for me... But the costumes looked AMAZING. I'll give you some examples. They looked so completely unique and gorgeous. I wish I had those costumes. FIND EXAMPLES OF COSTUMES
And in a turn of events that is completely unlike me...I'll admit that I sorta-kinda liked the romance. The lovers were sweet on each other. I really liked allthose epic hug scenes. (Which basically were fake outs on Zen's part.) And the promise they made? Pretty cute. But I'm not entirely won over. Not yet. Prove that you deserve each other\n
Dislikes:\n\n
Shirayuki is a boring girl...but a smart one. I didn't particularly care for her Disney princess personality. She was too kind. It annoyed me. She had no depth. But she, admittedly, quite smart. She figures out the answers to problems quite quickly. (But I figured some of it out before she did. So HA! I'm kidding.) For example, the mysterious illness in Ladox was something she figured out quickly. I figured it out too, but I think everyone did. (It was pretty obvious.) But she was quite smart. Not very...perceptive, though.\n
In the beginning and end of almost every episode, one of the two main characters (Zen or Shirayuki) would talk about paths and fate. And it made me annoyed. Why in the world would they keep mentioning it? One time is fine. More than one is just...tiresome. I kept skipping those parts. It was a serious waste of time.

This felt really good to watch. This is an anime that I was unsure about to start off with, but it was something different to me. I try to explain it in the categories, because everything felt special. 
Story: As a story, you have many of the same tropes that you have, but it surrounds what I would call  the relationships, that Shirayuki experiences during her time in the castle (not really trying to go into detail because i'm avoiding spoilers).  The story I'll give an 8. 
Art: As art I can describe it in one word beautiful.  It really does suckyou in, due to the fact that the show takes it time to make you love the setting around you. Even from the opening alone it shows how well the art is done. The art I give a 9. 


Sound: Now im going to start this off with the intro, and ending stuff. Honesty I did not care for the opening, or the ending. Both of them are great do not get me wrong, but it really takes a lot to get me into an opening.  As for watching it Sub, or Dub I did watched the dub.  The dub, is worth watching (and I know a lot of people will say that they don't watch dubs but this one worth it). The dub has Austin Tinstale which he has become a if he in it I watch it (because I liked him in 91 Days). The sound I give a 7. 


Characters: Something interested  in me in the characters in this show. Shirayuki is not a dansal in distress which I loved,  It great and refreshing to see a girl who does not depend on anyone else. Even though Zen (the main male) is protective of her, she is still independent for herself. The side characters can b the comic relif at times, but they are important too. Characters are a solid 10 for me 


'Enjoyment, and Overall: As an enjoyment value I give it a 9, I got what I needed to enjoy it. Overall value is an 8, I will be giving the second season a watch definitely  recommend this, for people who want a strong female character, and for something a little light on the fantasy side.

I honestly did not expect to stay so impressed by this series. The story revolves around Shirayuki, forced to flee because of the usual stupidity and tyranny of rulers, but in the end, despite opposition and difficulties, she will find her happiness. 
The secondary characters are very well made and surround the whole story in fine fashion. Although it is obviously a love story, the humor is not left apart and often some smiles and laughters are spontaneous. Attention should be given to the soundtrack. Awesome. Really a strong point that accompanies the whole story in a sublime manner. I gave a very high mark,but I sincerely believe that this Anime is of great quality and deserves to be seen.

TL;DR Above Average anime with good visuals and characters. It does feel a bit cliche at many points, and does not know whether it wants to be a romantic-comedy with dramatic elements or a pure 50/50 between romcom and drama. This confusion lead to me feeling it had a long run time, despite only being 12 episodes long.
I really like romance anime, and I like the idea of re-imagining Snow White as a story line. When I heard this anime came out with fairly good reviews, I put most of the other anime I had been watching to allow myself some time to watch this.I did not expect to find the next golden standard of anime with this one, but an enjoyable experience. For the most part, I was satisfied when I finished this season of Snow White with Red Hair.


The story of Snow White with Red Hair is a pretty standard fantasy, romantic-comedy where a common girl who is unusually beautiful compared to the rest of the commoners finds a prince of another land who falls in love with her. After this realization, the anime turns into a slowly growing tale of affection between its two main characters Shirayuki and Zen. It is also a tale that emphasizes how the importance of hard work and contacts can lead you to hopefully to that "happily ever after" ending that many of us have been instilled from many forms of entertainment. While all of those ideas and morals are great to try to have within an anime, which isn't a totally unique message to send, this anime does lag down quite a bit.


The reason why I think it lags is because the story does not know what it wants to become. There is plenty of instances where viewers learn about herbology and alchemy through Shirayuki's lens, and political acumen through Zen's life. However, it clashes with itself due to the show's sense of comedy, which is very innocent in its nature. The show doesn't know if it wants to be a romcom with serious elements like Oregairu or anime that is 50/50 romance to serious tensions like Spice and Wolf.


This confusion only grows stronger when I look at its list of characters: Obi, Zen, Shirayuki, Kiki, Mitsuhide, and Izana. All of them seem to have the same level of ditziness, but extreme seriousness. While I would say that works in a lot of anime, it only added to the confusion due to the lack of focus of the storyline in this anime. All the characters felt like added timelines to what should be a good, disposable anime.


The reason why I say it's ok to have a disposable anime is due to the fact that, this show's whole premise feels overused already. I feel like there is not a need for a show like this unless it's willing to push the note to extremely places. And, it definitely does not.


Before I conclude, I will say that this anime does look very nice. The world is beautifully animated with bright colors and shadowing that gives a nice finish to the overall series. The way that this series does wind is quiet calming to me as well. The animation can get choppy at points, especially during the middle parts of the series when characters are doing fine motor actions like grinding up stuff or getting off horses. Additionally, the sound in this show is nothing to write home about. The opening and ending were ok at best, and I cannot seem to remember any of the background tracks during the show. I wouldn't say it has a bad soundtrack because nothing sounded off-kilter to me. It definitely does not stand out though.


Snow White with Red Hair is a romantic-comedy, despite all of my bagging on it, is an above average anime. It has great looking visuals and likable characters. The biggest problems that I have with this show is that its story doesn't know, if it wants to be serious or light-hearted. I am fine with either option, but this constant switching back and forth slowed down the pacing of this anime to where it felt like a slog to finish the last few episodes. If you are looking for a solid romantic-comedy anime to spend a few hours with, I would say this might be worth a look. (6.6/10)

-Plot and Story Line-
For a twelve episode long anime, the story line is pretty solid and even tough you get the feeling that the plot is a little bit forced and rushed it actually fits pretty good. I loved the fact that they did not only concentrate on the relationship between Zen and Shirayuki although it is the main story line. There were a couple of side stories, a couple of background stories and some little extra story lines that supported the main one.
Most important thing for me, there were no plot holes and the story is pretty interesting too. I also had to laughhard a couple of times. This anime is awesome if you just want to relax and forget your problems for a couple of hours. It makes your heart melt a couple of times but it doesn't cause any stress and that kind of stuff. My recommendation, watch it over the weekend after a hard week and you'll feel much better right after. 

One thing that'll made me remember this anime is definitely the, let's say, character trend in anime. The thing that Sakura did in Naruto or Yona in Yona of the Dawn is actually better known in some cartoons as Mulan and The legend of Korra. The main character cuts her long hair to show that she is a new person now and that she is taking another, stronger and more independent path than before. I personally loved that move, because I love independent and strong female characters, but seeing it a couple of times now, it got a bit boring. I don't thing it will fascinate me in another anime again,  but we shall see. 

True the anime is cute but I don't think I could watch the second season. At least not now. There is too much cliche romance in it and I found that a bit annoying. But, I am not a great romance fan, meaning it is actually my subjective way of thinking. If you like romance, you'll love Akagami no Shirayuki-hime. 

Still, the anime is not perfect which is why I rated it as a 8 on MAl. One reason is the lack in background information about Shirayuki's life. Where are her parents? What did she do all her life? Where does she come from if her hair was so unusual? Not sure if the second season tells us more, but the first one left a huge question mark in my head. 

In the end I gotta say, I wouldn't have mind if there were a couple of episodes more between the beginning and the highlight of the first season. The show was cute, nice to watch and interesting. Thumbs up!


-Characters- 


The characters are the second reason I rated this anime with an 8. They are too perfect to be good cahracters. I always say, characters with flaws are better because they have sth to work on when it comes to their personality. That's what makes them interesting.


-Animation and Style-


If there is one segment of this anime that deserves a higher note than 10/10 then it is the animation. It is really awesome and beautiful. I can't remember any anime that had such a good animation. Truly amazing. Bright and colorful settings, detailed characters and backgrounds and amazing details.  When it comes to the style of Akagami no Shirayuki-hime, there is nothing much to say. Just like the animation, it is flawless. I loved it and will definitely from now on use this anime as an example of amazing animation. One more thing. While watching the first episode I actually thought of quitting because I found it a little bit stupid in the beginning, but I continued because of the animation. I couldn't miss such a great animation work being someone that hates and usually skips anime with bad animation.  



-Conclusion-

If you had a really thug week and you need an anime just to relax and forget about the world for a day, watch Akagami no Shirayuki-hime. It will take you on a little journey, to a different universe where everything is nice, cute and perfect. It will melt your heart in a couple of scenes but you will survive it. I liked the anime even though it was annoying in some moments but you can get over it. The animation and the character and background looks will please your eyes like no anime before. Give it a try and if you decide to watch the second season too, tell me how it was. 


Your AnimeGirl <3

The concept for the anime is refreshing and the story is very wall written, both as an overarching plot and as individual episodes. I was especially thankful that episodes were very well self contained, with no unnecessary cliffhangers bogging down the story. It made them flow very naturally into each other and hadn't even noticed I'd watched all twelve episodes. 
There was noting to complain about with the art, but neither were there enough om-gawd moments to warrant it a perfect score. The same is true for the sound.
I enjoyed watching the characters unfold and develop, but some of the minor characters and episodic villainswere slightly cliched. Additionally I wanted the former noble from early in the series to be a recurring character.\n\n
As I said earlier, I didn't even notice that as the anime went and finished. That was because I was having such a good time watching I forgot how long I'd been watching. A very enjoyable anime.\n\n
Overall it did nothing wrong and did a lot right, but it didn't go above and beyond my expectations of it. It was a fabulous anime and I am looking forward to watching the second season; but I worry that season two will make the same mistake several anime do, and will take the beautiful ending from season one, open it back up and then not end it properly come season's end.

Mirror, mirror, on the wall, what anime is among the most romantic of them all? Could it be one where the protagonist is a girl with hair the color of apples, and she falls in love with the second prince of a country that is not her own? Oh my, I'd say that's very romantic! How could I have encountered it other than it being among the July 2015 anime I missed out on and deeply regret doing so? More importantly, now that I've watched it, what do I think of it?
Well, you shall find out by reading my review of season one of SnowWhite with the Red Hair, known in Japanese as Akagami no Shirayuki-hime.


Snow White with the Red Hair follows a girl named Shirayuki (meaning snow white), who is an herbalist with bright red hair. She ends up catching the attention of Prince Raji, the prince of her country of Tanbarun, and he tries to make her his concubine. Shirayuki responds by cutting her hair and escapes to the neighboring country of Clarines. She ends up meeting the second prince of Clarines, Zen, and his two aides, Mitsuhide and Kiki, and she ends up being saved from Prince Raji by them. It is then that Shirayuki decides to become a court herbalist for Clarines. As Shirayuki aims for a new life in Clarines and Zen tries to become a worthy prince, they support each other, and a romance blossoms between the two.


I should start by saying the animation is among the most beautiful I've ever seen. Bones has done great animation before, like in Space Dandy, Noragami, Ouran High School Host Club, and more, but the animation in Snow White with the Red Hair is definitely up there with the best. I've fallen completely in love with the opening theme, "Yasashii Kibou" by Saori Hayami, and the ending theme, "Kizuna ni Nosete" by eyelis, is a very good song, too. I watched this anime's English dub, and I'd say that Funimation has nailed yet another dub. The voice actors had performed very well, especially Brina Palencia as Shirayuki and Josh Grelle as Prince Zen.


The story was quite an easygoing one, but it definitely provided a lot of character development. Speaking of characters, this anime had a lot of great characters. Shirayuki is a strong protagonist, and it's admirable how she always works hard. Zen is equally as likable, if not more; it's clear that he really cares about Clarines and its people. I honestly didn't know how to think of Obi, who works for Zen, at first, but I eventually grew to like him. There are also a lot of interesting side characters, but I think the side character that stood out to me the most was Mitsuhide; I really liked his friendship with Zen.


What could be the best part about this anime, though? Well, it doesn't take a detective to figure out that I'm talking about the romance between Shirayuki and Zen! They had a very strong bond as friends, but whenever they would have those tender, romantic moments, I just can't help but smile. This is probably going to be a bit of a spoiler, but the best part is that they actually confess their feelings for each other instead of letting it drag on for too long! ....Okay, I lied; it was very late in the season when they confessed. Hey, thank God for the currently-airing-at-the-time-of-this-review season two, right? This means we'll actually get to see them as a couple, albeit in a different season.


Overall, Snow White with the Red Hair is off to a fantastic start. I'd recommend it to anyone who is in the mood for a great romance anime. Be warned, though, not to bite into the apple that makes you think it's anything like the fairy tale "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs", because although there are two references in the first episode, it's poison not to think of it as anything less of its own story.

Disclaimer: If you’re a fanboy or apologist who can’t even critique outside of the box you’ve constructed for yourself, then please fuck off? 
	Apparently red hair makes you famous like dank memes - Shirayuki no Akagami review
Akagami no Shirayuki, or Snow White with the Red Hair is about Shirayuki a girl with an apple colored red hair who’s trying to escape from the obsessive and pampered Prince Raj, and is indefinitely saved by the second Prince of Clarines, Zen. There our journey begins. I’d say there isn’t exactly a story, as suppose to it being more of things happening in their everyday life. Correct meif I’m wrong. Still, I found this show an enjoyable watch not just because it’s cute, rather that the characters are well crafted and suited for the entire premise and concept of the setting. Which of course makes it cute? Well sounds a bit redundant there but good characters equate to an overall elation. But more importantly, did it piss me off? No. But it’s not without its criticism. One such I have is where are the king and queen in all of this, did I miss something? I know for sure they’ve never been mentioned.


	Now let's get art and sound out of the way. Bones the studio behind shows such as Wolf’s Rain and Eureka Seven, they put effort where it was needed, the entirety of Akagami no Shirayuki. Voice acting is subtle and adds onto the emotions of each character, while not exasperatedly intense nor fantastic, it holds up well enough. The soundtrack greatly helps improve your pleasure of watching this show. It gives off the romantic vibe well placed in scenes appropriate to a scene’s tone. The opening and ending are just a good listen and it captures that lovely prince and princess esque feeling, a little bit.


	Ah, characters, probably the most important element of any show, with the story being the latter. I’ll just say I’m not well verse in shoujo, but that doesn’t mean my points are invalid. I watch more than just anime, I am such a screen junkie, I’ve watched tons of movies and T.V. shows that I can tell if something is cliche or just unbelievably stupid. Even if a lot of reviews are saying there are shoujo cliches in Akagami no Shirayuki, then I’d have to disagree and say, it’s a well crafted cliche done well. But that’s the point I want to make. I’ve digressed far enough. Our main heroine, Shirayuki, is somehow a unique person because of her red hair, but I found it odd that there is also people like Zen with white hair and Mitsuhide with green/blue hair? What am I saying? I’m nit picking now. But still it’s odd, wouldn’t you say so as well? Anyhow, Shirayuki proves in the first few episodes that she is a capable main protagonist and heroine by showing and using her knowledge of herbalism, and wits to escape dangers such as the bandit guy who kidnapped her. While I don’t think she could’ve taken the handle of the series on her own, it is because her dynamic as well as Zen rely on each other. The second Prince of Clarines, Zen, for a while is your typical prince who disobeys his work and goes off to play around like the common man. But as progression comes by, we learn just how dark and gritty the series can get, and a reasonably good explanation for why Zen acts the way he does. Both Shirayuki and Zen are of a ying/yang, each with their own character flaws that compensate for one another. Mitsuhide, Kiki, and Obi’s role are to play as the consolation for Zen at moments of his dark past or troubles as the prince, or with Shirayuki. They offer enough to the overall narrative, doing their job as written to help progress the character development of our protagonists. Although I find it weird that Obi is listed as a main character, I can see subtle but very obvious hints to why they may have, and I pretty much guessed it before clicking on his spoiler button. One of the key focuses of the character is the relation of royalty and the common man. It is good to see that Zen is a progressive character, but not without his struggles to push past the dark past that holds him back at times. And then he would eventually do that one ‘thing’ we all want to see in a romance, much appreciated, earlier than we’d expect. Other characters like the first Prince of Clarines, Izana and the herbalist people, they do their part to help as well to develop our main character’s resolve and teach them along the way. Overall characters, they are crafted exceptionally for what it is.


	To end this all, this show earns a 8/10, and misses my badass seal of approval. Akagami no Shirayuki proves to be a good watch and one I can’t necessarily recommend, even though looking at my score it should be, it’s not anything special, just well crafted. However if you’re looking for a ‘similar’ show I ‘d say watch Akatsuki no Yona, that show is dank overall, even though the first 3 episodes or may probably turn you off, it almost certainly did for me, but it pays off tremendously. Akagami no Shirayuki did you like it? What did you think of it? Planning on watching it because of this review? Comment on my page to let me know you enjoyed my rational and logical review.

Like many other people, I started watching Akagami no Shirayuki-hime to spend my spare time in a sorta relaxing way, I am all for light stuff this period that can make me smile a little and feel better XD Enough with the gabfest, let's get to the important part:
STORY: 7.5/10 
It's not something spectacular, pretty simple actually. But quite solid as well. No plot holes, no cringe-y moments in the romantic moments of the show, the romance is actually really cute and well-developed. Same for the comedy. About action, well it's not really there, if you mean by action something intense, somehow lasting and sortof dark. The anime has a strong slice of life feeling IMO and it's a great match with the imaginary medieval scenery of it. Also, the pacing is really good. Everything about the plot creates a warm and relaxing atmosphere for someone who watches Akagami no Shirayuki-hime, an atmoshpere I associate with my feeling of everlasting rest when I am lying on my bed covered with my blanket. During the first 5 episodes you might wonder where does the anime aim at because the main characterization is still not 100% complete, but don't feel like you might end up wasting your time, things become pretty clear afterwards, maybe even predictable for some, but still upcatching and enjoyable. This first season will surely seem to many of you too calm, but that gets balanced by the beggining of the second season, which I am gonna review after finishing this review, so don't feel like there is no evolution in the story, it's just the beggining. 


ART: 9-9.5/10

Beautiful backgrounds, beautiful character designs, incredibly good colouring. Then why not a 10? Well, because I might have wanted some extra detail in the character's faces, but that's just me extremely nitpicking now, everyone looks so damn attractive.


SOUND: 8/10

I really like the score, very light and discreet, perfect match with the picture.  I love the opening, it's just really beautiful and I also praise the singer, who is also the main protagonist's, Shirayuki's, voice actress.


CHARACTERS: 9/10

Great character development, perfectly formed to fit the anime's general aura, they are light, some of them cute and funny, straightforward, balanced and not overdramatic at all. Every character, especially the main cast, feels complete and interesting. When it comes to the main heroes and heroines particularly, I think they shine even more when they are all together. You might just miss that extra something that will make you able to *love* them, not just to really really like them because well... everything is done right.


ENJOYMENT: 8/10

I had a great time watching it, I enjoyed the characters, their funny, serious and romantic moments, and went immediately to the second season, hoping that some things will be excelled there.


OVERALL: 8/10

I think that Akagame no Shirayuki-hime is surely gonna entertain a lot those who are interesting in the anime genres it represents. It was treated very well and it was really well made. I suggest you watch directly the second season because you will get a wider aspect of the show and trully feel the whole experience.

I'm sure Akagami no Shirayukihime would be great to watch as a stand alone, but seeing as how I'm first and foremost a fan of the manga, the anime was disappointing. What disappoints me the most is how the characters in the anime are portrayed differently than in the manga. Characters like Zen and Mitsuhide are passable, but I'm ambivalent about Obi, and even more so about the female characters Shirayuki and Kiki. Starting with Obi, while he is mischievous and playful to a degree in the manga, there are instances where they over-amplify these characteristics in the anime that seem gratuitous. Kiki, who isconstantly solemn faced even when she is teasing others (most notably Mitsuhide), gave me a stupefied double take when she was seen acting AND looking coy with Obi in the show. Shirayuki, though known to show more expressions than Kiki, is also a serious and poised character. While Shirayuki does have her moments of fumbling and gracelessness, those moments in which they appear in the show seem ill-fitting. It also doesn't help that the voice actress makes Shirayuki sound naive and overemotional when I imagined it to be more calm and charismatic.

This is the best Shoujo anime I've ever seen. That's not saying much, because I don't think Shoujo as a genre has much to offer in the first place, but if you like watching two characters totally meant for each other fall head over heels in love with one another and in general gooey, happy feelings, then this show is for you.
Be aware, though, that this is only the first season, and another cour is already planned for release in Winter 2016.
Starting us off will be the story department. It's nothing that hasn't been done before, what with the handsome prince saving the beautiful maidenfrom certain disaster and all that jazz. But this show pulls it off that I feel is actually sort of believable given its medieval setting, and I didn't mind the more cliche aspects of it, since there were little things here and there that made it feel more realistic. The main heroine, Shirayuki, for example, is actually a talented herbalist, and her goal in getting closer to the prince, whom she's obviously fallen for after having been saved by him, is to become an official court herbalist. She actually has a talent that she uses and improves on, and she's incredibly hardworking, which was refreshing to see. She also is pretty competent on her own, and in most dire situations she gets herself into, she often is able to almost pull herself out of it, and it ends up making one feel that, though she didn't need the Prince's help, it's still nice to see the guy save the girl at the end of the day because rainbows and butterflies. But overall, the story doesn't actually do anything special, and it's really just about an unlikely relationship between two people of different classes and how they struggle to come to grips with their feelings for each other.


The art is where I was actually expecting something better considering it was done by Studio Bones, but I actually found the character designs and background art to be pretty boring. Nothing bad, but everything kind of screamed generic, even though you technically could say it was all fairly pretty looking. The animation was pretty good, again, no stand out moments in particular besides perhaps a certain fireworks scene toward the end of the series, but there wasn't ever really much to anime in the first place. There is a lot of dialogue, a lot of viewing scenery, but also several fight scenes, and those are all actually well done. I appreciated their inclusion to break up the monotony of courtly meetings, walks in the courtyard, office discussions, and other fairly boring events, animation-wise.


The music was all very pretty. That's honestly the best way I can describe it. Not beautiful, but it was pretty. The tracks were often very soothing, and just added to that same "gooey" feeling of fluttering happy feelings of the show. Voice acting was pretty good, but I felt like the MC prince Zen was trying way too hard for a lot of his lines. Hayami Saori does a good job as usual portraying the plucky Shirayuki, but I don't actually like her voice that much in the first place, so it was a struggle for me personally. She did a good job though. Also, the OP and ED are very good and pleasant to listen to every time.


The characters are the best thing about this show. Everything is set up to be the most generic idea for a show ever imagined, but the things you learn about the characters and the way they act are refreshing actually. Shirayuki, as I mentioned before, is actually capable of taking care of herself, and she doesn't actually need to be rescued in most situations. She has convictions and goals, and she actively works to achieve those goals. Zen is a lot more nuanced of a character, and his motivations and backstory are both very interesting. The flashbacks of his past actually add a lot to his character, and he feels very complex and I'm not sure I know everything about him yet, which is good. The side characters get barely any attention, but they're side characters in a shoujo after all.


Objectively speaking, I'd only rate this show a 7 or 8, but enjoyment-wise, I'd give it a solid 9. If the visuals had been more impressive or the soundtrack more moving, I'd have given it a 10. But honestly, it just did the right things. It was gooey, that's really the best word to describe it. Just feels good, man.


Overall it's a nice break from predictable shoujos in that it presents its story in an interesting way that just lets you take a break from life. It doesn't require serious thinking, nor is it tiresome or boring, or nauseating even. It feels good.

Akagami no Shirayuki-hime is easy to describe: A wonderful love story anime with amazing art, typical characters but still enough comedy to have a good time and enjoy watching :D
The story of the anime is not very surprising and yes, I can say that without spoiling, there won't be many surprises and twists in this anime. Maybe some interesting storylines but nothing too major. 
AnS is one of those anime you may want to watch every so often, when you are depressed or when you just want to watch a light hearted spring-like anime. This anime offers all that plus some touching scenes which goto your heart but at the same time don't make you cry your eyes out for three days...


AnS also offers wonderful drawings. The character but mostly the amazing landscapes and the clothing details on the royal uniforms and other small details make the art of this anime really amazing and touching. Most of the time it also has a very light and spring coloured touch so don't expect many dark and gloomy scenes.


Overall I really enjoyed the anime, mostly because I really hoped for an anime like this for a long time. 

BUT if you want a dramatic masterpiece of art, sound, story and characters I have to say...you won't find it here. 


AnS offers romance from beginning 'til end. It gives you just enough drama to keep the romance alive without crying to much and enough comedy to laugh inbetween. It is the perfect anime for inbetween others and to have an enjoyable romance unfolding in front of you =)

Akagami no Shirayuki-hime is an anime I've been waiting for for quite a while. When I discovered the manga, I instantly fell in love. When the anime came out, I didn't like it at first, because the characters looked different from what I was used to, but the story was spot-on, but I soon got used to it.
Story (7/10):
Like almost every anime with romance as it's main focus, there's not much story to it. But with this anime, there's practically a different plot to every episode, you can clearly point out what the episode was about and how it was different from the others.
Art (10/10):
Theart was very beautiful, great scenery, and adorable art style. As I said in the beginning, the art was much different from the manga, but it's still adorable.\n
Sound (10/10):\n
There's not much to say about this, really.\n
Character (7/10):\n
When watching anime, I always look for the character's background story , or what happened to the character in the past. There's not much background in this anime, especially in the main female character, Shirayuki, in which the story revolves around her.\n
Enjoyment (9/10):\n
I laughed on funny parts, blushed and cried on cute parts. I loved it.\n
Overall (8/10):\n
Like most people say, "The manga is better," I'd say that's true for this anime, although the anime has more elements that manga does not have.\n\n
Recommend:\n
I'd recommend this anime to people who like romance and shoujo anime. I also suggest to read the manga, but that's not required.\n
If you watched Tamako Market or Tamako Love Story, you might also like this anime.

I’m please to say that going into ‘Akagami no Shirayuki-Hime’ I had expectations and they were fulfilled to say the least. I loved this anime. So what can you expect if you decided to give it a chance?
First of all –and very crucial- it is a Fairy Tale. Which means it is very romanticized and cutesy. Not that there isn’t some action! Like regular fairy tales there are parts with swordfights, damsels in distress and evil people that want to harm said damsels.
The Characters are good! And Shirayuki is not a damsel really. But due to her hair colour and connections to the prince doesget herself involved in all sorts of situations. She’s a bit blunt at points but the anime is a shoujo fairy tale, so I can’t really complain knowing that. Would I preferred her being a bit more kickass? Yes. And is she a little too perfect? Yes, again. I will admit that. But, it never reached a point where she made me sigh in exasperation and say ‘ok, now you’re just messing with me!’ She does talk back and runs into action when she needs to.


Zen is also a fairy tale prince. For anyone who has seen ‘Kaichou wa Maid Sama’ reminds me a lot of Usui. He is a bit too perfect as well. But, like Shirayuki, that character aspect never really did annoy me. He can get carried away and has a tragic past –as all Shoujo manga/anime boys should have apparently- but I never hated him for that. On the contrary he is sweet and caring and that is totally fine in my book.


Something that really pleased and I will sound immature for saying so but, I’m an otaku woman and I appreciate that in anime, were the rich palette of guys. Good, evil, sweet, mischievous; there are types for all kinds of preferences. 


From the first episode I understood the feeling of this anime. It’s very relaxing in general. Even if there’s conflict throughout the episode it never tires the viewer. At the same time, whatever conflicts are taking place, they are resolved by the end of the episode. By the end of the anime –and I don’t really think I’m spoiling anything here- everything is resolved and we get our happy fairy tale ending. Well, not really ending, as there is a sequel.

An anime I immediately compared it too is ‘The World is still Beautiful’ a.k.a. ‘Soredemo Sekai wa Utsukushii’ If you like that Anime I recommend watching ‘Akagame no Shirayuki-Hime’ and vice versa.


In conclusion, it’s a beautifully drawn anime, with interesting ( a bit too perfect sometimes) characters and good plot that never tired me. If you are into hardcore action, this anime is not really for you. If you want a light adventure, that contains a bit of humor and romance with cutesy moments then ‘Akagami no Shirayuki’ just might be for you.

I know this anime already has a second season, so I ain't gonna talk about the ending of the series. I mean there's a second season!
Short Summary:
Shirayuki, the main heroine of the series is a girl born with unique apple-red hair. She meets the famous but foolish Prince Raji who falls in love with Shirayuki at first sight. He then gives an order to Shirayuki to become his concubine.
Shirayuki, having nowhere else to go, cuts her hair and escapes to a neighbouring country. while going through the forest she encounters a boy called Zen.
After Shirayuki boldly cures his wounds Zen helps her but he isthen poisoned by and apple that was given to Shirayuki. During this time Prince Raji sends his henchmens to search for Shirayuki.\n
What will happen afterwards? Who is Zen?\n\n
So before I go any further; you can tell there's going to be some sort of romance between the characters.\n
I mean this series IS a romance genre series.\n
Moving on for romance series I have to say the characters are somewhat dense... (You will somewhat get it when you watch it)\n
